data.title: The blockbuster movies that put Hampshire on the silver screen, from Bond to Les Mis and Gladiator
data.meta_description: Hampshire has offered a range of filming locations to Hollywood directors, from country homes to cathedrals and woodlands
data.text:
There's a chance that some of your favourite films could feature scenes shot on your doorstep.

Scores of blockbuster movies have been filmed in Hampshire over the years, using our county's magnificent historical sites, country homes and countryside to capture that perfect setting.

007 himself is no stranger to Hampshire - and award-winning films including Les Miserable, Gladiator, War Horse and the Da Vinci Code have put us on the silver screen.

Here we've got a list of more than 30 films that feature scenes shot in Hampshire - how many do you know about?

We've also thrown in some brilliant TV series for good measure.

If we've missed one from our list, let us know in the commenting section at the end of the article.

War Horse (2011)

The Oscar-nominated film based on Michael Morpurgo's beloved novel of the same name follows the story of a young man who enlists to serve in World War I after his beloved horse Joey is sold to the cavalry. The movie follows Albert’s journey out of England and onto the front lines.

All the cavalry scenes from the movie were filmed at the country house at Stratfield Saye, home to the Duke of Wellington.

Director: Steven Spielberg

Stars: Jeremy Irvine, Emily Watson, David Thewlis

Quantum of Solace (2008)

Part of the epic James Bond series, Quantum of Solace was Daniel Craig's second-star turn as the secret agent and sees 007 battle to stop a mysterious organisation from eliminating a country's most valuable resource.

Scenes from the movie were filmed at Aldershot Military Barracks, Montgomery Lines due to its unique architecture. Farnborough Airport also made an appearance in the movie.

Director: Marc Forster

Stars: Daniel Craig, Olga Kurylenko, Mathieu Amalric

Inception (2010)

The Oscar-winning, mind-boggling sci-fi adventure took us into the subconscious and beyond with a plot with more twists and turns than England's country lanes.

The state of the art airfield at the TAG Farnborough Airport featured in the 2010 film, which became the fourth-highest grossing film of 2010.

Director: Christopher Nolan

Stars: Leonardo DiCaprio, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Ellen Page

Becoming Jane (2007)

The biographical movie follows the life of Jane Austen, pre-fame and based on her own letters, as well as her romance with a young Irishman.

The world-famous author spent most of her life living in Hampshire. Many of the movie's scenes were filmed at her former home, the Jane Austen’s House Museum, Chawton - which is still open to the public.

Director: Julian Jarrold

Stars: Anne Hathaway, James McAvoy, Julie Walters

Les Misérables (2012)

Tom Hooper's epic musical movie based on the long-running theatrical production swept the awards ceremonies that year with an A-list cast taking on the roles of Jean Valjean, Javert, Fantine and Cosette in a story of poverty, revolution, faith and love.

Two of Hampshire's iconic locations feature: Portsmouth Dockyard and Winchester College.

Director: Tom Hooper

Stars: Hugh Jackman, Russell Crowe, Anne Hathaway

Tomorrow Never Dies (1997)

Another Bond classic on our list, the 18th in the series and the second to star Pierce Brosnan as James Bond. This time 007 sets out to stop a media mogul's plan to induce war between China and the UK in order to obtain exclusive global media coverage.

James Bond film ‘Tomorrow Never Dies’ (1997) showed shots from onboard HMS Westminster at Portsmouth Naval Base.

Director: Roger Spottiswoode

Stars: Pierce Brosnan, Jonathan Pryce, Michelle Yeoh

The Da Vinci Code (2006)

Based on the smash-hit novel by Dan Brown, the thriller sees a college professor caught up in a murder inside the Louvre, strange clues in Da Vinci paintings, and the discovery of a religious mystery protected by a secret society for two thousand years.

In the movie, Winchester Cathedral doubled as the Vatican.

Director: Ron Howard

Stars: Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou, Jean Reno

Gladiator (2000)

Are you not entertained (by this list)?! The 2000 bagged five Oscars for the violent and heart-wrenching story of a former Roman General who swears vengeance against the corrupt emperor who murdered his family and sent him into slavery.

Some of the war scenes were filmed in Alice Holt Forest, Farnham.

Director: Ridley Scott

Stars: Russell Crowe, Joaquin Phoenix, Connie Nielsen

Sahara (2005)

The adventure-comedy follows an explorer seeking out a lost Civil War battleship known as the "Ship of Death" in the deserts of West Africa - while helping a WHO doctor being hounded by a ruthless dictator.

The opening scenes of Sahara (2005) were filmed at Hawley Lake.

Director: Breck Eisner

Stars: Matthew McConaughey, Penélope Cruz, Steve Zahn

Die Another Day (2002)

Another Bond entry in our list, and another Pierce Brosnan adventure. James Bond is sent to investigate the connection between a North Korean terrorist and a diamond mogul, who is funding the development of an international space weapon.

Hawley and Parts of Aldershot’s military training area were also used for scenes in this James Bond film.

Director: Lee Tamahori

Stars: Pierce Brosnan, Halle Berry, Rosamund Pike

Avengers: Age of Ultron (2015)

Yep, Hampshire even has a claim on the Marvel mega-series. The 11th film of the Marvel Cinematic Universe sees Earth's mightiest heroes joining forces to stop the villainous Ultron from enacting his terrible plan.

Captain America and The Avengers team visited Hawley Woods in 2014 to shoot scenes for the Marvel Cinematic Universe film.

Director: Joss Whedon

Starring: Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans, Mark Ruffalo

Transformers: The Last Knight (2017)

The fifth instalment of the Transformers series sees a deadly threat from Earth's history reappear. A hunt for a lost artefact takes place between Autobots and Decepticons, while Optimus Prime encounters his creator in space.

Parts of the Hollywood movie were shot in Gosport.

Director: Michael Bay

Starring: Mark Wahlberg, Anthony Hopkins, Josh Duhamel

Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom (2018)

The second instalment of the Jurassic World trilogy sees Owen and Claire mount a campaign to rescue the remaining dinosaurs after the island's dormant volcano roars back to life.

Opening scenes for the adventure film were shot at Pyestock. It was filmed through the night and involved helicopters, rain machines, and lightning simulators to mimic a thunderstorm.

Director: J.A. Bayona

Starring: Chris Pratt, Bryce Dallas Howard, Rafe Spall

Children of the New Forest (1998)

Set in the 1640s during the English Civil war, the film sees four children smuggled into the forest to hide. There they encounter various adventures in before joining a conspiracy to help King Charles.

Several scenes were taking place at the 16th century Elizabethan Breamore House, Fordingbridge, and surrounding Tudor village.

Director: Andrew Morgan

Stars: Tom Wisdom, Joanna Kirkland, Malcolm Storry

Wilde (1997)

The 1997 film explores the life of poet and playwright Oscar Wilde, as he discovers his homosexuality.

The tranquil grounds of Houghton Lodge, Stockbridge were used in filming scenes from the award-winning film.

Director: Brian Gilbert

Stars: Stephen Fry, Jude Law, Vanessa Redgrave

Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves (1991)

A classic if only for the late Alan Rickman as a panto version of the Sheriff of Nottingham, the 1991 film saw Kevin Costner take the starring role as Robin Hood fighting side by side with the outlaws for justice.

Scenes for the movie were shot at Highclere castle and grounds.

Director: Kevin Reynolds

Stars: Kevin Costner, Morgan Freeman, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio

Emma (1996)

Based on the Jane Austen novel, this 1996 adaptation follows Emma matchmaking for friends and neighbours but nearly missing out on her own chance at love.

The dining room at the country house at Stratfield Saye, Home to the Duke of Wellington was used to shoot scenes for Emma.

Director: Douglas McGrath.

Stars: Gwyneth Paltrow, James Cosmo, Greta Scacchi, Alan Cumming

World War Z (2013)

Brad Pitt starred in this zombie apocalypse film based on the popular Max Brooks novel. Former United Nations employee Gerry Lane (Pitt) traverses the world in a race against time to stop a zombie pandemic that is threatening to destroy humanity itself.

Scenes from the movie were filmed at Aldershot Military Barracks, and Montgomery Lines due to its unique architecture.

Director: Marc Forster

Stars: Brad Pitt, Mireille Enos, Daniella Kertesz

Rush (2013)

The film is based on the merciless 1970’s rivalry between Formula One rivals James Hunt and Niki Lauda.

Several scenes were filmed at Blackbushe Airport, Yatlely where the old airstrip was used for racing clips.

Director: Ron Howard

Stars: Daniel Brühl, Chris Hemsworth, Olivia Wilde

Fierce Creatures (1997)

Hampshire’s 140 acre Marwell Zoo doubled as ‘Marwood Zoo’ in Fierce Creatures (1997). The movie followed the zookeeper's struggle to deal with the policies of changing directors.

Directors: Fred Schepisi, Robert Young

Stars: John Cleese, Jamie Lee Curtis, Kevin Kline

Children of Men (2006)

In 2027, in a chaotic world in which women have become somehow infertile, a former activist agrees to help transport a miraculously pregnant woman to a sanctuary at sea.

The scenic ten-mile Watercress Line from the town of Alresford to Alton has featured in many series and documentaries including Children of Men.

Director: Alfonso Cuarón

Stars: Julianne Moore, Clive Owen, Chiwetel Ejiofor

Angela’s Ashes (1999)

Based on the best-selling and heartbreaking memoir by Frank McCourt, the film follows a family as they try against all odds to escape the poverty endemic in the slums of pre-war Limerick.

The movie features the Steamship Shieldhall in opening scenes and its closing, which can be visited at its home in Southampton.

Director: Alan Parker

Stars: Emily Watson, Robert Carlyle, Joe Breen

Oscar and Lucinda (1997)

An Anglican minister and a rich heiress meet aboard a ship, a mutual obsession blossoms. And they make a wager that will alter each of their destinies.

Portsmouth Historic Dockyard and HMS Warrior were used as the backdrop for the film.

Director: Gillian Armstrong

Stars: Ralph Fiennes, Cate Blanchett, Ciarán Hinds

Elizabeth: The Golden Age (2007)

The second film starring Cate Blanchett as the British icon, The Golden Age sees a mature Queen Elizabeth endures multiple crises late in her reign including court intrigues, an assassination plot, the Spanish Armada, and romantic disappointments.

Scenes from the movie were filmed at Winchester Cathedral.

Director: Shekhar Kapur

Stars: Cate Blanchett, Clive Owen, Geoffrey Rush

The Secret Garden (1987)

The TV movie follows the life of a spoiled little English girl who is orphaned in 19th century India. She is sent back to England to live with her uncle, where she discovers many secrets.

Scenes for the movie were shot at Highclere castle and grounds.

Director: Alan Grint

Stars: Gennie James, Barret Oliver, Jadrien Steele

Van Wilder 2: The Rise of Taj (2006)

The sequel to National Lamppon's Van Wilder sees Taj Mahal Badalandabad leaves college behind for the halls of university where he looks to teach an uptight student how to make the most out of her academic career.

Several scenes from the movie were shot at Winchester College.

Director: Mort Nathan

Stars: Kal Penn, Lauren Cohan, Daniel Percival

Golden Compass (2007)

In a parallel universe, young Lyra Belacqua journeys to the far North to save her best friend and other kidnapped children from terrible experiments by a mysterious organization.

Some scenes were shot in the Alice Holt Forest, Farnham.

Director: Chris Weitz

Stars: Nicole Kidman, Daniel Craig, Dakota Blue Richards

Tommy (1975)

The iconic British film based upon The Who's rock opera album of the same name sees a psychosomatically deaf, dumb and blind boy becomes a master pinball player and, subsequently, the figurehead of a cult.

South Parade Pier, Portsmouth was used as one of the locations in this movie.

Director: Ken Russell

Stars: Roger Daltrey, Ann-Margret, Oliver Reed

Diamonds are Forever (1971)

Yes, another Bond movie, but this time with Sean Connery. A diamond smuggling investigation leads James Bond to Las Vegas, where he uncovers an evil plot involving a rich business tycoon.

Part of this Bond movie was shot in Southampton Docks.

Director: Guy Hamilton

Starring: Sean Connery, Jill St. John, Charles Gray

Kabhi Khushi Kabhie Gham (2001)

The 2001 Indian Hindi-language melodrama, which translates to 'Sometimes there is joy, sometimes there is sorrow' sees wealthy Rahul is disowned by his family for marrying a poor woman - so he moves to London for a new life. Years later, his brother Rohan sets out on a mission to bring Rahul back home and reunite the family.

Scenes for the movie were shot at Highclere castle and grounds.

Director: Karan Johar

Stars: Shah Rukh Khan, Kajol, Amitabh Bachchan

Goodbye Mr Chips (1929)

An aged teacher and former headmaster of a boarding school recalls his career and his personal life over the decades. Goodbye Mr Chips has been made into two films and two TV series, but in the 1939 outing some scenes were shot at the Winchester College.

Directors: Sam Wood, Sidney Franklin (uncredited)

Stars: Robert Donat, Greer Garson, Terry Kilburn

Eyes Wide Shut (1999)

Eyes Wide Shut is an erotic mystery psychological drama film set in New York City. A doctor embarks on a harrowing, night-long odyssey of sexual and moral discovery after his wife reveals a painful secret to him.

Scenes for the movie were shot at Highclere castle and grounds.

Director: Stanley Kubrick

Stars: Tom Cruise, Nicole Kidman, Todd Field

Get Real (1998)

A tenderly romantic coming-of-age story as two boys in a British school fall in love.

The entire film took six weeks to shoot and was filmed in and around Basingstoke. Key locations included: Cranbourne School, Down Grange Sports Track and Millstone Public House.

Director: Simon Shore

Starring: Ben Silverstone, Brad Gorton, Charlotte Brittain

The Monuments Men (2014)

George Clooney stars and directs the war film in which an unlikely World War II platoon is tasked to rescue art masterpieces from Nazi thieves and return them to their owners.

The movie was filmed at Bramley Camp in the heart of the village.

Director: George Clooney

Stars: George Clooney, Matt Damon, Bill Murray

Stardust (2007)

In a countryside town bordering on a magical land, a young man makes a promise to his beloved that he'll retrieve a fallen star by venturing into the magical realm.

Minley Manor was used as a location in the movie.

Director: Matthew Vaughn

Stars: Charlie Cox, Claire Danes, Sienna Miller

TV series filmed in Hampshire

Downton Abbey (2010 onwards)

Perhaps the most known example of filming in Hampshire, the ITV hit drama Downton Abbey used Highclere Castle as the home of the Carnarvon family.

Set between 1912 and 1926 the show depicts the lives of the aristocratic Crawley family and their servants.

Creator: Julian Fellowes

Stars: Hugh Bonneville, Phyllis Logan, Elizabeth McGovern

Inspector Wexford (1990s)

The series was shot near Romsey, a pretty market town with a good selection of shops and restaurants.

Director: Katie Kinnaird

Stars: George Baker, Graham Benson, Val McDermid

The Day of the Triffids (2009)

The miniseries was the second adaptation of the 1951 novel made by the BBC. With most of the world blinded and the dangerous carnivorous Triffids set loose, it falls upon a band of scattered survivors to fight this plant invasion and the madness following.

Parts of the TV show were filmed at the Hospital of St Cross in Winchester.

Creator: Richard Mewis

Stars: Dougray Scott, Joely Richardson, Eddie Izzard

The Buccaneers (1995)

The TV miniseries tells the story of four American girls who have travelled to London to find husbands - only to discover that English upper-class men are not at all what they expected and hoped for.

Much like Wilde (1997) scenes from the period show were shot at Houghton Lodge, Stockbridge and the pier which was built especially for this show, is still there today.

Stars: Carla Gugino, Alison Elliott, Mira Sorvino

Wartime Farm (2012)

Wartime Farm is a British historical documentary TV series in eight parts in which the running of a farm during the Second World War is reenacted.

Manor Farm Country Park, Southampton was used in the miniseries.

Stars: John Simm, Peter Ginn, Ruth Goodman

Howard’s Way (1985–1990)

Tom Howard is made redundant from his job as a senior aircraft designer and decides to invest his skill, time and redundancy money in a run-down local boat building yard.

The TV series was set on the River Hamble (Hamble, Bursledon & Swanwick).

Creators: Gerard Glaister, Allan Prior

Stars: Jan Harvey, Stephen Yardley, Glyn Owen

Worzel Gummidge (1979–1981)

Children's series about the adventures of a scarecrow who comes to life. Two orphans arrive at a farm who meet him and join him in the adventures.

The series was filmed in the Test Valley areas of Stockbridge, Kings, Somborne and Braishfield.
